@enothereska I think KAFKA-3537 was filed for exposing the metrics registry to allow users to register their own, while this PR is for exposing the metrics map in read-only manner as we did for other clients, i.e. it should be really targeting https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3701? If you agree, could we update the PR title then?

EDIT: thinking about this a bit more, I feel there are some further differences in KAFKA-3701 and KAFKA-3537: 

1. If we want to add the read-only metrics map as we did for other clients, for the purposes of health checking / building their own metrics mechanism based on this `getter` API, then it is better to be on the `KafkaStreams` class to return the `Map<MetricName, ? extends Metric>`. (KAFKA-3701).

2. If we want to allow users to registry their own metrics by leveraging the library's metric collector, then it is better to be added on the `StreamsMetrics` class, which returns the `Metrics` object (KAFKA-3537).

@stepio I am actually aware of a couple of `MetricsReporter` implementations, and some of them comes from `confluentinc` open source repos :P Personally I agree that your fix is actually more ideal, and that we did make a mistake at the very beginning when writing `MetricsReporter`. But for retaining backward compatibility we'd probably have to go with the sub-optimal approach.

I have synced with @ijuma about this, and either myself or Ismael will be happy to help review and merge this once you refactored this PR.

@enothereska What I meant is mainly around user experience: by having task / processor-node level metrics to be distinguished by the thread name (e.g. define sensor name as  `thread.streams-thread-XXX.task.1-1.PROCESSOR-XXX-processor-throughput`), users then need to enumerate all possibly created sensors in their monitoring system and / or web UI, while only one of them will be valid / having non-blank graphs at a given point of time; on the other hand, since at any given time only one thread will be owning the task / processor node, it is safe to collapse them into a single sensor that could be accessed and updated by different threads at different times, and users then can simply polling / monitoring this single sensor (e.g. `task.1-1.PROCESSOR-XXX-processor-throughput`).

Thanks @cmccabe . Removed  javadoc changes. Note, I had only removed modifiers when they are implicit defaults, for eg: interface methods are default public, enum constructors are default private.
Please let me know what you think. thanks!

The JDK 8 and Scala 2.11 build failure was `QueryableStateIntegrationTest.queryOnRebalance[0]`, which is unrelated to this PR (the test is a bit flaky).
@hachikuji, added one minor commit and fixed merged conflicts. OK to merge?

2 big questions here.

1) whether this needs to go through the KIP process.  @ijuma  mentioned that in the jira
2) Whether we want to pull from luben/std-jni, which is someones private repo? It is bsd licensed but its not in apache so any bug fixes and such they would have to pull in and question about maintenance and such.  Since BSD licensed probably could just copy or could also copy the Hadoop implementation ones.  Anyway this is more question for the Kafka committers.
